unnormalised: Someone asked me if Dr. and Prof. are the same thing. Well, not exactly, bhai. Let me try to explain it simply for you. In India, especially when we're talking about medical professionals, there's a bit of a hierarchy and different roles. "Dr." is pretty straightforward – it’s short for Doctor and means someone has earned a doctoral degree, like an MBBS or MD. You'll call pretty much any medical practitioner "Dr." whether they're working in a big hospital like AIIMS or running a small clinic in your mohalla.
normalised: Someone asked me if Doctor and Professor are the same thing. Well, not exactly, brother. Let me try to explain it simply for you. In India, especially when we are talking about medical professionals, there is a bit of a hierarchy and different roles. "Doctor" is pretty straightforward – it is short for Doctor and means someone has earned a doctoral degree, like an M-B-B-S or M-D. You will call pretty much any medical practitioner "Doctor" whether they are working in a big hospital like A-I-I-M-S or running a small clinic in your mohalla.

unnormalised: Now, "Prof." or Professor is a title that usually applies to someone who's teaching at a university or medical college. They’re not just practicing medicine, but also involved in research and training the next generation of doctors. So, Dr. Sharma who treats patients at Max Hospital might also be Prof. Sharma if they lecture at a medical college affiliated with Delhi University. Often, senior doctors who've contributed significantly to their field will get the "Prof." title.

Often, senior doctors who have contributed significantly to their field will get the "Professor" title.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: all Professors are Doctors, but not all Doctors are Professors. You might see Dr. Kumar, a renowned cardiologist, who operates regularly but doesn't teach. He's a fantastic doctor but not a Prof. On the other hand, Dr. Sen, the head of department at CMC Vellore, also teaches and conducts research, so he's rightly called Prof. Sen. It is kind of a mark of academic distinction on top of their medical practice, if that makes sense?

unnormalised: It can get a bit confusing with different specialisations though. You might hear "Dr." used more loosely, even for someone with, say, a PhD in Biochemistry doing research in a hospital lab. That person isn't treating patients directly, but they're still contributing to healthcare. Sometimes, "Mr." or "Ms." are used for surgeons, particularly in the UK and other Commonwealth countries, irrespective of their other academic qualifications. You might encounter this if you're reading medical literature from abroad.

unnormalised: So, the short answer? "Dr." is the general term for a medical practitioner. "Prof." indicates an academic position, usually involving teaching and research at a university or medical college. Hope this clears things up! And remember, whether they're Dr. or Prof., respect your medical professionals – they're doing important work.
